item.title: Lipid Brain Atlas Released
item.description:
We are excited to announce the release of the Lipid Brain Atlas - a high-resolution mapping of membrane lipids in the mouse brain!

This work, led by Luca Fusar Bassini in collaboration with Giovanni D’Angelo’s lab, reveals that lipids act as zip codes for fine-grained brain anatomy.

Key Discoveries

Lipizones: A New Way to Map the Brain

We discovered lipizones - brain territories defined purely by lipid composition, without any anatomical assumptions. Remarkably, lipid profiles alone can predict 3D brain tissue coordinates with high accuracy.

Oligodendrocyte Heterogeneity

We found striking lipid heterogeneity among oligodendrocytes in the corpus callosum, suggesting that these cells are far more diverse than previously appreciated.

Connecting Cell Bodies to Axon Terminals

Lipid signatures can connect cell bodies to their distant axon terminals, opening new ways to study brain connectivity through biochemistry.

Ventricular System Zonation

We uncovered biochemical zonation patterns in the choroid plexus and ventricular linings, regions critical for cerebrospinal fluid production.

Pregnancy and Sex Differences

Perhaps most surprisingly, pregnancy triggers coordinated membrane adaptations across brain regions. We also found sex differences in white matter sphingolipids that amplify during pregnancy.

Why This Matters

The atlas enables tracking how disease, aging, diet, and medications reshape brain lipid composition at the cellular level. This opens new avenues for understanding: - Cell-type specific metabolism - Developmental history encoded in membranes - Connectivity patterns revealed through lipid fingerprints

Explore the Atlas

The interactive atlas is available at: lbae-v2.epfl.ch

Read the full preprint on bioRxiv.

item.title: The Lipidomics Architecture of the Mouse Brain
Mapping the lipid blueprint of life in 4D
Antonio Herrera appointed Group Leader
item.description:
We are proud to announce that Dr. Antonio Herrera, a postdoctoral researcher in our lab since 2021, has been awarded a prestigious Ramón y Cajal fellowship!

Toni will start his own research group at the University of Granada, Spain, in the second half of 2026.

During his time in the La Manno Lab, Toni has made fundamental contributions to our research program, including developing computational methods for spatial transcriptomics analysis and contributing to multiple high-impact publications. His work on deep learning methods for imaging and spatial biology has been particularly impactful.

We are excited to see Toni establish his own independent research program and look forward to future collaborations. Congratulations Toni!

item.title: Specialized signaling centers direct cell fate and spatial organization in a limb organoid model
Unified Mass Imaging Maps the Lipidome of Vertebrate Development
Congratulations Dr. Irina Khven!
item.description:
We are delighted to announce that Irina Khven has successfully defended her PhD thesis!

Irina’s thesis, “Fine-grained mapping of neural progenitors subtypes in the embryonic brain unveils context-dependent roles of signalling on cell fate decisions,” represents a major contribution to our understanding of brain development.

During her PhD in the EDNE program (2019-2025), Irina made fundamental contributions to mapping neural progenitor diversity using spatial transcriptomics and single-cell approaches. Her work has been instrumental in establishing the lab’s spatial transcriptomics capabilities and generating some of the most comprehensive datasets on embryonic brain development.

Irina will continue her scientific career as a Postdoctoral researcher at the Institute of Molecular and Clinical Ophthalmology Basel (IOB).

Congratulations Dr. Khven, and best wishes for your future research!
